comment_text: When "The Da Vinci Code" came out, much of its notoriety arose from its repeated claims of "truth". Brown was asked in various media about this, and he always affirmed the ridiculous, religious conspiracy theories that form the backbone of this otherwise routine airport thriller (the hero runs breathlessly from crime to crime uncovering mystery after mystery, etc.). At my job, the only question co-workers asked me about this book (because I'm familiar with actual history, religion and art) was, " Is this stuff really true??!!??"  Really, it's all bogus. And from what I understand, even the real-world geography is wrong. Even the the word "symbology" (Langdon's alleged academic field) is a dumbed-down rendition of the actual field of "semiotics" (see Eco''s 'Foucault's Pendulum' for a much better-informed conspiracy thriller). I was given the book by someone who told me that it was exactly the kind of thing I liked. I enjoy occult conspiracy, secret knowledge, intellectual shenanigans, so in that sense they were right. But I hated The Da Vinci Code.

Firstly, it's very badly written. The language isn't expressive or interesting, neither is it punchy and impactful.

Secondly, the characters are pretty non existent: each character is difficult to describe except by their job and some base elements of physical description. No-one has a personality.

Thirdly, the book reads like a travelogue. Every location is introduced with what reads like text lifted from a tourist brochure.

Fourthly, events happen which stretch credibility far too far. I have known since I was a kid about Da Vinci's mirror writing. I am not the world's foremost Da Vinci expert. Yet, it takes the experts in the book ages to think of it when it should be instantly recognisable to them. This is an example - there are many others.

Fifthly, the framing device (claiming the book tells only the truth) is obvious bollocks and very insulting to the reader as well as potentially misleading to the most naÃ¯ve.

Sixthly, the conspiracy theory at the heart of the book waa stolen from Holy Blood, Holy Grail. I don't mind a little theft in a good book, but this isn't a good book, so it's another negative.

If you want to read an actually great conspiracy thriller try Foucault's Pendulum.

Dan,

I just wanted to let you know that The Da Vinci Code was truly incredible for me. Not just because of the story, but because of my experiences caused by the novel. 

I was 14 when your book came out. It was  only after a couple of days that it was released that my family and I took a vacation to England and then Paris. I picked up your book in the airport before the flight. I read the book at every opportunity. 

By the time we got to Paris, I was nearly done with it. My family and I went to the Louvre. I had the book in my backpack with no intention of reading it in the museum. We were seeing many exhibits, but I unintentionally got separated from the rest of my family at the Venus exhibit (we were staying in a hotel a block away, so no big deal.) I decided to seize this opportunity to explore the museum and try to see as much as possible. 

After I got my fill of the museum, I finally went to the information booth and notified the curator that I was lost from my family. She sat me in a chair and let me wait there. Remembering the book, I started reading The Da Vinci Code. 

I managed to finish the book looking at the inverted pyramid. I couldn't believe it. I kept looking up in disbelief. Was I really there? Did I seriously finish the book at the location of the ending? I almost screamed I was so excited. I still believe that I am the first person to unintentionally do that with your book. 

I eventually close the book after rereading the ending a bunch of times and gazing in aww at my surroundings. The curator comes over to tell me the museum is closing soon and notices that I'm holding the book. She was shocked to see it. I told her I just finished it.  She told me that the book was actually banned in France due to its scathing views of Interpol and that you couldn't find it anywhere. I offered for her to have it and she couldn't believe it. She offered to make it up to me and told me to follow her. 

So I, a 14 kid, follow this random French Louvre curator, to an employee area, and she gives me a behind-the-scenes tour of the Louvre. She introduced me to a jeweler who was restoring the French Crown Jewels (which the exhibit was closed for that reason. ) He showed me a crown and scepter.  The curator introduced me to some historians who showed me some pieces that weren't on display. And other inter-workings of the museum.  I couldn't believe how nice everyone was (mind you this was at a time when Freedom Fries were a thing.)

She then took me to the Louvre gift shop and bought me a photo book of the Louvre and a Coke. 

She walked me halfway to my hotel and we parted ways. I didn't even know her name, but she kept thanking me for the book. 

Also, I was stopped by two street artists who did my portrait (at the same time) for free. They said they were having a contest and who did a better job. I chose the one that had the Eiffel Tower in the background, even though you can't see the Eiffel Tower from the view that he drew me. Haha. 

When I got to the hotel, my family wasn't there. I waited for them and when they got to the room, I told them what just happened to me and their jaws practically hit the floor. 

So...thank you Dan Brown. Thank you for writing a novel that lead me to have one of the best times of my life. I will never ever forget that day. I own all of your books and am currently reading Inferno. I will forever be a fan of your work.

comment_text:
> There was no symbolism.

Not really on topic, but I feel like this is a weird stance on writing that I see a lot, that symbolism is big, serious, binary idea. Either it's some huge bold metaphor that covers the central idea of the book, or it's not there. 


But symbolism is an almost inescapable part of writing in an interesting or evocative way. Dan Brown is a pretty straightforward writer, but there's a *ton* of symbolism in The Da Vinci Code (ignoring the literal "symbology" part of the plot, obviously!). Symbolism doesn't even *need* to be totally explicit & intentional (although I am very confident that at times, it would be in Da Vinci Code), if you just try and write an interesting story, it will pop up naturally as you go. That's just how our mind works, when we lay out compelling stories, symbolic elements pop up.

Not really relevant to the discussion, this certainly isn't any notable part of Da Vinci Code's success, but symbolism is just a fundamental part of writing.

comment_text:
OK Snatch_Pastry, let's see if I can convince you.

(First of all, cool screen name.)

OK, here goes. SPOILER ALERT!!!!!!!

>Is the Florentine the diamond or an adversary group?

It is neither.  In fact the Florentine is a cyber-weapon. Alex Fife, the book's protagonist thinks that the Florentine is a diamond based on some initial sleuthing, but eventually finds out its true nature.  The book is about his quest to determine the nature of the Florentine, and then to stop it from getting in the wrong hands, where it will be used to cause an immense amount of damage.

>It's geek/tech, so is it closer to: Michael Crichton, Neal Stephenson, William Gibson, or Tom Clancy? Or to go way out on a limb, Larry Niven's "Dream Park"? Can you draw parallels to one or more of these authors?

Hmmm.. I'd say it's closest to Chricton's works.  It It can best be described as a plausible, easy-to-read technology-flavored adventure.  However, unlike Chricton's novels, there are no elements of the story that couldn't actually happen in real life.  It's more like science fact-fiction than science fiction.

>You already mentioned the da Vinci Code. I loathed the ending of that book, because after a fun read through the art/architectural/historical sites of Europe and a huge build up, it ended with a total cop-out whimper. Can you categorically state that your novel has a real ending, with cool reveals and a satisfying sense of conclusion? A cliff-hanger/lead in to a sequel is also acceptable.

Yes - I can definitely promise that the end of the book has an exciting, realistic conclusion. It's not a cliff-hanger, but a  technological duel between Alex and some very bad folks who want to use the Florentine for ill ends. You, the reader, will likely wonder how you'd stop the attack. Can you come up with a clever solution that won't do more harm than good? The technological premise of the book is actually feasible, and at the end of the book, the main character is faced with saving the U.S. computing infrastructure from a realistic cyber-attack. If you don't think that attackers could decimate our computing base (permanently), think again. It's eminently possible. And in fact Eugene Spafford (PhD @ Purdue, he wrote the book's foreword) previously warned the U.S. Government of this exact style of attack.

>How about a bit more about Alex. What's some background on him, and why should we like him?

Alex Fife is a 25-year old recent college grad who founded a startup in his UCLA dorm room and sold it for nearly $300M. Now he has more money than he can spend, and yet he's bored. What do you do with your life when you've achieved your life's ambition and made it. He's a success by every definition of the word. Yet he's lost and looking for something to bring his life meaning.  And he finds it in an old computer.  

Alex is a rock climber, a jokester, a good friend, a good son, and a bit to hasty to act.

>Is it available in .epub?

Absolutely! From iBooks and on Nook.

comment_text:
Well, when it comes to fast-paced thrillers, such as your aforementioned *The Da Vinci Code,* the genre is far from dead. In fact, Dan Brown recently released his fourth installment in the Robert Langdon series, titled *Inferno,* and it's already a New York Times Bestseller. James Patterson and Dean Koontz are still going strong, as well. As far as vamp books and 50 Shades nonsense, that's all aimed at a particular audience, namely 14 year-old girls. I'm not sure an intellectual would consider either of those two to be quality reads. Basically, the genres still stand in popularity, I think. Christians still buy self-help books from Joel Osteen and Joyce Meyer. Sci-fi nerds still buy the classics (I, myself, have an extremely difficult time finding new, exceptional modern sci-fi). And typical readers buy whatever is on the bestseller lists. If any genre is going to take the cake and top all others, it's fantasy. The Game of Thrones TV series sort of re-sparked, if you will, the fantasy interest left void after Lord of the Rings waned in popularity. After reading the first two books of *A Song of Ice and Fire,* I can confirm that George R. R. Martin truly has penned a masterpiece of works with this quintessential series. Fantasy is no longer confined to the realm of fairies and goblins and such; it has progressed, largely, if not solely, due to Martin's presence, to a point where reality and fantasy collide. We are taken to a time without science, knowledge of medicine, or much knowledge of anything really. There are dark times, yet Martin accurately portrays the ways in which people, in this case the charcters of *A Song of Ice and Fire,* handle situations such as true life-and-death. There is romance, passion, and sex. There is violence, fear, and death. This is no different from today's reality in the sense that there is ongoing war and suffering that can never quite be relinquished. Martin has redefined the fantasy genre, and I'm sure many more authors will follow suit and pen works unlike others beforehand.

**TL;DR** Da Vicni Code-type books (i.e. action thrillers) are far from losing popularity. Twilight and 50 Shades are only popular because they are marketed for and read by tweenage girls, and there are millions of that demographic. Fantasy is swiftly regaining mainstream popularity, largely due to the success of HBO's Game of Thrones and the work it was adapted from, George R. R. Martin's *A Song of Ice and Fire.*

I have never read Dan Brown- I read a few pages of Da Vinci Code and soon put it down; the quality of the writing just wasn't there for me. Plus I like a degree of  intellectual challenge. The Da Vinci Code relied on sensationalism and absurd premises to hook the reader, so I suspect it satisfied the page turning urge and in the end was a good yarn.

Good yarns though, do not make great, or even good, literature.

What they do make is lots of cash- and this is the issue with modern publishing. It is about the formulae that has worked once, so let's stick to it and produce more of the same because it sells.

Popular fiction is not only formulaic and hackneyed, but it has to have plenty of sequels lined up. In any bookshop or library you see this all the time: Part Two of the Hand of Darkness trilogy, Another Inspector Wobble mystery. People like to feel at home with their books, so will read the same author over and over because they trust the writer to produce more of the same.

I think you are learning valuable lessons about what makes good writing, as opposed to the mediocre stuff.

Once you have expanded away from this type of thing and into real quality literature you will not turn back.

This isn't really a criticism of any writer, often they are under immense pressures to produce more of the same by the publishing houses, just as with artists in the music industry who get tied into contacts which stultifies and does not develop, their creativity. It is very sad.

comment_text:
may i re-frame the question?  because the answer depends a lot on how you're defining "culture" and "significance".  based on your post, you seem to be defining those as "American" and "popularity", respectively.  and yes, in those terms, the da vinci code & harry potter series probably do win.

but i don't personally think they're *significant*.  they were *popular*, but i would define the significance of a book as the power & influence it has on changing cultural beliefs/perceptions in lasting ways.  "game changers", so to speak.  will anyone care about da vinci code or even harry potter in a hundred years?  i'm guessing probably not, at least nowhere near as much as today.  but which books *will* be remembered that far ahead, and perhaps even *grow* in readership in the future? that's the question, and it's also extremely difficult to make judgments like this so soon.

there's also a difficulty in that things have become so sub-categorized and specialized that it becomes difficult for any one book to have an impact across the entire culture.  there are probably scientific books that are making huge waves through their respective disciplines, but have zero recognition from people outside of those disciplines.  fiction, too, is split up into many genres, so that it's rare for one fiction book to be read by a wide variety of readers.  or if it does, it doesn't happen right away--the reputation builds first within the genre as being a masterpiece, and then slowly begins spreading to other types of readers who give it a try.  but still that takes a lot of time, more than a decade i think.

that said, i have no idea what to suggest as a book that spreads across genres and probably will have an even bigger readership as time goes on.  sorry if all this was ultimately unhelpful. :P
